banner.subtitle: Unlock the tremendous potential of the Federal Government’s software.

help_wanted.title: Ready. Set. Code!
help_wanted.description: Whether you are a beginner or an experienced coder, join the open source community. Help improve America's Code.

banner.search_description_text: Search for federal open source software projects and usable code

home.aboutus: Code.gov is the federal government's platform for sharing America's open source software
home.mission: Our mission is to help agency partners and developers save money and increase quality by promoting code reuse and educating and connecting the open source community
home.vision: Serve as the community leader in driving code reuse and open source development to decrease code spend while increasing code quality

explore.title: Developers
explore.description: The Code.gov website is developed publicly on GitHub. Learn how to contribute here. Help improve America's Code by exploring projects.

explore.title: Connect with Us
explore.description:
Have questions or feedback? Open an issue on our open source repository.

Want to receive our quarterly newsletter?

explore.title: Agency Partners
explore.description: Federal agency partners use Code.gov to share usable open source code, promote open source projects, and track compliance with federal open source policy.

news.title: Federal Source Code Summit: Towards a Source Code Community
news.description: Code.gov will host its first annual Federal Source Code Summit...

news.title: Front-End Updates Provide Greater Accessibility for America’s Code
news.description: Last month we celebrated the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act...

news.title: Better Know an Engineer: Rayvn Manuel
news.description: We’re back with another installment of Better Know an Engineer...

about.title: About Us
about.description: Code.gov is on track to become the nation’s primary platform for sharing America’s code.  Find out how we’ll get there.

about.title: Policy Info
about.description: The Federal Source Code Policy helps government agencies reduce duplicative software development and save taxpayer dollars.

about.title: Progress Report
about.description: Government agencies are working hard to unlock the potential of code sharing and collaboration. Here’s a quick snapshot of their progress.

featured.author: Environmental Protection Agency
featured.description: A python package designed to simulate and analyze resilience of water distribution networks.
featured.alt: A network of pipes with a red, yellow and green valve and a meter gauge

featured.verbose_name: Intelligent Transportation Systems Operational Data Environment
featured.author: Department of Transportation
featured.description: A real-time virtual data router that ingests and processes operational data from various connected devices including vehicles, infrastructure, and traffic management centers and distributes it to other devices and subscribing transportation management applications.
featured.alt: Cartoon truck navigating windy road with caution sign and wireless towers

featured.author: National Security Agency
featured.description: Enables security teams to integrate apps, workflows, and analytics tools that would otherwise need to be created from scratch.
featured.alt: Cartoon hand pressing buttons connected to phone and laptop

press.quote: It’s the latest in a long line of high-profile victories for the open source movement.

overview: At Code.gov, we know it’s important to keep an open dialogue with our users. That’s why we’re sharing our plans for the future through this Development Roadmap (aka Roadmap). Hopefully, it provides a better understanding of our priorities for the platform.

The Development Roadmap is organized into three categories – Near-term, Mid-term, and Long-term. Priorities are sorted into roadmap categories based on feedback we receive during user interviews. Dependencies and resources are also factors that affect placement on the roadmap. If you want to join a Code.gov user testing group, please email us at Code@gsa.gov.

near.name: Build out the Federal Source Code Toolkit
Migration of web components to React components
Continue enhancing automated testing across site
SSP annual review and update (for API ATO)

mid.name: Find new solution for code quality reviews

long.name: New validator tool w/ new schema
Website search capabilities, integration w/ Search.gov

roadmap.disclaimer: This Development Roadmap (Roadmap) is for informational purposes only. The Code.gov team will update the Roadmap as frequently as possible but it is subject to change at any time. The information presented by the Roadmap should not be used for planning purposes. The information presented in the Roadmap does not represent a solicitation or similar contract vehicle. All items in the Roadmap will be developed and released at the sole discretion of Code.gov and the U.S. General Services Administration.
